subsc: General industry and trade sector,General transportation sector,General energy sector,General finance sector,Central government administration

abstracts.cdata!:
The implementation of the project was
            rated as partial and the outcome unsatisfactory. The key
            lessons learned include: 1) Government commitment is
            important. The government needs to build confidence through
            steady and consistent implementation of reforms. There is a
            perception that over the past decades, Kenya undertook
            reforms in fits and starts. This intermittent approach to
            reform has undermined confidence among aid sources and
            business circles about government commitment. Staff turnover
            was cited as a factor affecting commitment to
            implementation. 2) A coherent policy design is important.
            Given that containing the growth of the government wage bill
            was very critical for consolidating fiscal and financial
            stability, as well as improving the management of public
            resources and redirecting support to priority non-wage
            activities the social sectors, the design of the reform
            program could have been more effective in capturing the main
            pressures points on the wage bill. 3) Performance on
            economic governance measures was less than expected, and
            this affected overall policy performance. Key economic
            governance issues, especially combating corruption,
            enhancing transparency in budget allocation, expenditure
            reporting, and enforcing accountability for the use of
            public resources are now at the center of dialogue with the authorities.
